results.title: In the company of whales
results.creator_credit: Robin Brown, TVNZ, Channel Four Television and Discovery Networks
results.brief_description: Narrated by Jessica Tandy, this visually stunning documentary shows phenomenal encounters never before captured on film. Whales are enormous, powerful creatures with extraordinary grace and intelligence. They are masters of a watery realm where they have existed for more than 30 million years. Filmed in 15 locations off the coasts of five continents, this affords a comprehensive look at whales (Blue, Sperm, Right, Beluga, Bottle-nosed whale and their small relatives the dolphin) and their environment. Guided by one of the world’s leading Cetacean experts, Dr. Roger Payne, a team of underwater cameramen reveal the mysteries of whale song, their sophisticated navigation techniques, their remarkable intelligence and affectionate social behaviour emphasising that they really are the gentle giants of the deep.

results.title: Trains remembered. - Volume 3.
results.brief_description: Ranging from the early 30’s to the late 80’s, this video utilises archival film to re-create the golden days of railway. In this volume Southern Railway trains are shown on their way to the seaside, Carlisle Station appears with electric locos followed by a collection of steam locos in 1966. Visit the Longmoor Military System in 1968, the Swindon Works in the 30’s followed by a visit in 1975 during the diesel- hydraulic era and a final visit in 1987. Witness the 150th Anniversary of the Festinog in 1986 capturing a gravity slate train in action and the 150th Anniversary of the London and Greenwich Railway in the same year. Also included is the famous Flying Scotsman from Kings Cross in 1968 and its USA trip.

results.title: Trains remembered. - Volume 2.
results.brief_description: Steam trains predominate in this unique and exciting video which features rare archival footage together with more recent material. Amongst the railway lines appearing are Little Kimble, Marlow, Colnbrook and Epping. A4’s and A2’s feature on the Kings Cross line, N2’s appear on suburban trains to Moorgate. Class 76 Electrics are shown on the Woodhead Line and in action in Holland for the last time in 1986. Witness the re-opening of the Isle of Man Steam Railway and the Kingsmoor Depot near Carlisle in 1966 which featured many steam trains.

results.title: Trains remembered. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Using archival footage and an informative commentary enthusiasts will be treated to a nostalgic look at the great days of railway. This volume captures steam and diesel engines dating as far back as the 1930’s including early green DMU’s, commuter trains at Liverpool Station in 1932, wartime NE A4’s and Class 78 Electrics, the Belfast 5‘3” gauge to Larne, 1950’s steam shed scenes, DEMU’s and in the 60’s KESR is taken over by the preservationists, trains at Euston, Paddington and Clapham, the last Brighton Belle, King George visits Paddington and finally a Bullied locomotive re-born in preservation.

results.title: Branchline railway
results.brief_description: Michael Palin, confessed train buff, introduces unique footage from the BBC archive: Branchline Railway and two historic newsreel sequences - a splendid requiem for the steam railway. “Branchline Railway”: the late Sir John Betjeman presents this little known film which perfectly captures the atmosphere of a 24 mile stretch of the now vanished Somerset and Dorset railway. It celebrates a working, living railway, complete with dirty locomotives, clean stations decked with flowers, and austere gas-lit waiting rooms. It all belongs to a vanished age but the film remains to delight and inform (broadcast 1963). “Britannia under her own steam” looks at the naming of the first magnificent Class 7 4-6-2 Standard locomotives ‘Britannia’ (broadcast 1951). “Atlantic Coast Express” is a footplate journey on Merchant Navy Class No. 35016 ‘Elder Fyffe’ as it heads the ‘Atlantic Coast Express’ (broadcast 1960).

results.title: Imran Khan
results.creator_credit: John E. Bodnar and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Imran Khan, the Tiger of Pakistan, was born into a famous cricketing family and became the most inspirational cricketer of his generation. From his early days at Oxford to his full test career with Pakistan, he has experienced unparralleled success as a genuine all-rounder. His test career, spanning three decades, has seen him develop from a precocious talent to a father-like figure exuding respect and experience. Features highlights of his playing career including his many records and achievements.

results.title: The Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras Parade
results.creator_credit: Stephen Jones, Susan Oliver and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: In 1994 the ABC chose to broadcast the annual Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras Parade live on Australian television. The decision generated much controversy but the public broadcasting of the event allowed all Australians to witness the joy and imagination involved in what is now one of the world’s leading festivals. This video of the broadcast includes footage not shown on the original screening. The Mardi Gras is a street festival in which lesbians, gays, queers and deviants can celebrate their communities and their determination to not be hidden from the public face of Australian culture. The theme of the 1994 Mardi Gras was “We Are Family” which aptly defines the strength of the Australian gay and lesbian movements in forging new forms of communal relationships which are working to challenge and destabilise homophobia. Testament to the Parade’s success is its ability to bring almost a million people onto the streets of Sydney to join in the celebrations.

results.title: Super sense. Part 2
results.brief_description: Imagine being able to experience the world through animal senses, to go on a unique journey into the heart of the animal kingdom. Using recently pioneered breakthroughs in filming and special effects photography, that journey is now made possible. This cassette contains three episodes: “Super scents”: Smell - it is the territorial signal of gazelles, the alarm system of impalas, the aphrodisiac of moths and salamandas. Stil more astounding, it is the sense that guides the salmon back to its birthplace where it travels to spawn and die. “Sense of timing”: A shrew lives its life thiry times faster than an elephant, the body clocks of marine animals measure tidal cycles… this innovative program reveals, as if by magic, the different time worlds in which creatures live. “Making sense”: Draws together the threads of the series and shows how the mind influences an animal’s view of the world.

results.title: Super sense. Part 1
results.brief_description: Imagine being able to experience the world through animal senses, to go on a unique journey into the heart of the animal kingdom. Using recently pioneered breakthroughs in filming and special effects photography, the journey is now made possible. Three episodes on this one cassette. “Sixth sense”: Animals showing special powers have often been regarded as ‘supernatural’ but this film reveals that creatures which possess a sixth sense are very much a part of the natural world. “Seeing sense”: Vision may be man’s best sense, but four-eyed fish which see above and below water simultaneously teach us that our sight is not the most sophisticated. “Sound sense”: Until now, we have been unable to hear the high-pitched squeaks of mice or the low-frequency calls whales use to communicate across hundreds of miles of sea. This episode opens our ears to a whole register of sounds. A natural landmark in natural history filming, this video is an extraordinary viewing experience.

results.title: Life sense: our lives through animal eyes. Part 1
results.creator_credit: John Downer, Lionheart TV International and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: How do we appear to the animals who share our lives? From the two million dustmites that inhabit our beds every night to the macaque monkey picking 800 coconuts a day - animals are an integral part of human life. As well as providing companionship and food, they live on our bodies and influence the climate and the very air we breathe. But what do they see? What is the influence of our actions on their behaviour? This unique six-part BBC TV series provides the answers using innovative film and video techniques to truly show how our lives appear through animal eyes. Part 1 contains three episodes - “Home life”, “Seeds of life” and “Partners for life”. Narrated by Andrew Sachs.
